instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> With Touchbar repair help
threads.message:
Real long shot as i cant find a schematic or BRD for this (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) 

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with liquid damage, a resistor is open circuit. It was pretty badly corroded. The pad underneath it was gone, There is no traces, the pad connected straight to a tiny Via that goes through the board, i have no way of knowing the value of the resistor or what it was connected to.

Anyone got one of these i could compare measurements with?
Thanks

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> With Touchbar repair help
threads.message: I only have a 13" here. :( maybe it is the same circuit? Can you take a picture of the area with the resistor, and then the resistor itself?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> With Touchbar repair help
threads.message:
No Title

Its right by the audio jack flex and another flex (maybe TouchID or something) 

Thing is everything seems to work, USB C, Touchbar, Audio, TouchID.ect

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> With Touchbar repair help
threads.message: The <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 13" board is different in that area so it might not be much help. On the 15" board I'm measuring 0.5Î© with the resistor on the board. Measured with a Fluke 115. The top pin is ground. The bottom pin is measuring .502 voltage-drop to ground in diode mode. That should help you find which line it's on. It's not connected to anything in the area that I can find. It might be the other side of the board.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> With Touchbar repair help
threads.message:
Thanks for the info BJF
Ive figured out the dead part, somehow the power button not working slipped by me.
I believe its the <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> line, Im going to poke around the macbook 12" schematics see if i can find anything interesting.
Im hoping its the same 10K resistor and cap to ground (it seems to have the cap to ground) used on older models.

Im looking for some debug pads, that could be a quick fix rather than looking for <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

Edit for quick update:
I was correct, that is the power button resistor, ive found debug pads, ran a quick ugly jumper and retested the button, All good now!

Will post pictures when ive given it a cleanup.
